data.title: Reviews of Albert Pinto Ko Gussa Kyoon Aata Hai
data.meta_description: Reviews of Albert Pinto Ko Gussa Kyoon Aata Hai
data.text:
it is hard to conceive in your mind that this film was released in 1981 and speaks volumes to the visionary that saeed akhtar mirza is

a movie made in the 1980s is exploring how women actually dress up for themselves and if they wear clothes of any length - its for themselves and not because they want every man to fall for them

tackling the impact cinema has on people and more so than that the caricature representation of…

Albert is an exceptional mechanic in a repair shop that caters to high-end customers. He values the status and modest pay bump his abilities have given him more than the camaraderie of his co-workers. He sets himself apart from them. Aspirational, he tries to spend more time with his wealthy clientele. Listening to their opinions. Echoing them.

This is a story of his awakening and radicalization. Albert's family and social circle feel pointedly placed: His father's a lifelong factory worker…

“bombay beyond the rose-tinted glasses”

what exactly makes albert pinto so angry? yes, this had been collecting dust in my watchlist for a minute and yes, THAT one line in merry christmas finally made me watch it and THANK GOD i did because wow. few points as usual:

-cinema did not exist before the 80s it was actually invented by my glorious queen shabana azmi when she called out the lack of goan/christian representation in indian media like THANK YOU…
